conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the Ampere force on the conductor rod MN at the initial moment.
The conductor rod MN is moving in a uniform magnetic field B with a direction vertically downward.
The rod is connected to a resistor R at both ends.
The rod has an initial horizontal leftward velocity v0.
The system is a spring vibration system with a light spring.
As the rod moves, it cuts through the magnetic field lines, inducing an electromotive force (EMF) E.
The induced EMF is given by E = B * L * v, where v is the velocity of the rod.
The induced EMF causes a current I to flow in the circuit.
The current I is given by I = E / (2R) because the rod is connected to two resistors in parallel.
The Ampere force F on the rod is given by F = B * I * L.
At the initial moment, the velocity of the rod is v0.
The initial EMF is E0 = B * L * v0.
The initial current is I0 = E0 / (2R) = (B * L * v0) / (2R).
The initial Ampere force is F0 = B * I0 * L.
Substituting I0, we get F0 = B * ((B * L * v0) / (2R)) * L = (B^2 * L^2 * v0) / (2R).
The Joule heat generated Q is related to the energy dissipated in the resistors.
The initial kinetic energy of the rod is (1/2) * m * v0^2.
The energy dissipated as heat is Q.
The initial kinetic energy is converted into heat and work done against the spring.
Assuming all initial kinetic energy is converted into heat Q: (1/2) * m * v0^2 = Q.
Solving for v0: v0 = sqrt((2Q) / m).
